pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the attribute `to_app`, which generates new declarations similar to how `reassoc` works.

The point is the following: given a lemma about an equality of 2-morphisms in some bicategory, `to_app` specializes this lemma so that the equality is taking place in `Cat`, then it applies `NatTrans.congr_app` and simplifies the resulting expression.

Lemmas of this form are useful to apply when working with a (simplified) expression of 1-morphisms in a category where parts (but not all) of this expression consists of components of natural transformations. So this attribute makes it easier to apply purely bicategorical lemmas in such situations.

A situation where I think that this is useful is when working with pseudofunctors valued in `Cat`. See the branch `bicategory-grothendieck-functoriality` for an example of where these automatically generated declarations are used. I think it might also be useful for 2-yoneda, as the pseudofunctors there are valued in `Cat` also.

Much of the code has been copied from `reassoc`. However, a new definition `toCatExpr` is added to specialize the lemma so that the equality is taking place in `Cat`. One also needs some amount of extra preprocessing to properly deal with universes (since `Cat` has a different dependence on universes than an arbitrary bicategory).

---

This seems very useful. I would review it if I knew anything about metaprogramming. Maybe @adamtopaz can take a look?
Thanks for the review @yuma-mizuno! All the suggestions were great, I have implemented them now + improved the error catching of the function.

Could you add a small test file? All this needs to do is import some file with a `to_app` attribute on some unlikely-to-change lemma, and verifies that the type of the generated lemma is what it is now.

Besides that, let's try it out.

bors d+

:v: callesonne can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10837199107/job/30072621083)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10837199107/job/30072622351)

I think this is a useful attribute to obtain `Cat` theorems!

I've left several comments.
lgtm after addressing additional comments.
`(· == B_pre)` works here. I think `B_pre` is sufficient throughout `toCatExpr` and you can avoid using explicit id `B`.

```suggestion
  let _ ← isDefEq B_pre (.const ``Cat [u, v])
```
Using `isDefEq` would be better.
Here also `isDefEq` would be better if there is no special reason.
My preference for doing this is using pattern matchings by e.g. `getAppFnArgs`. You can also use `conclusion.eq?` for the equality matching.
I think it's common to use `fun` instead of `λ`.
I think `[v, u]` is a consistent notation here.
Right, thanks!

It seems that we still need `Bicategory B` immediately after `B`. I attempted to remove this limitation by using `args` instead of `mvars`.
```lean
  let rec
  /-- Recursive function which applies `mkLambdaFVars` stepwise
  (so that each step can have different binderinfos) -/
    apprec (i : Nat) (e : Expr) : MetaM Expr := do
      if i < args.size then
        let arg := args[i]!
        let bi := binderInfos[i]!
        let e' ← apprec (i + 1) e
        unless arg != B && arg != inst do return e'
        mkLambdaFVars #[arg] e' (binderInfoForMVars := bi)
      else
        return e
```
Good catch, thanks a lot!

```suggestion
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Tactic/CategoryTheory/ToApp): Add `to_app` attribute
